ProjectDescr.Name: Treponema denticola ATCC 35405
ProjectDescr.Title: Causes periodontal disease, gum inflamation
ProjectDescr.Description: Treponema denticola ATCC 35405. Treponema denticola ATCC 35405 was isolated from a human periodontal pocket and is the type strain of this organism.

StructuredCitation.Title: Comparison of the genome of the oral pathogen Treponema denticola with other spirochete genomes.

Journal.JournalTitle: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

Author.Consortium: The Institute for Genomic Research, 9712 Medical Center Drive, Rockville, MD 20850, USA.

ProjectDescr.Name: Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum str. Nichols
ProjectDescr.Title: Causative agent of syphilis
ProjectDescr.Description:
Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum. This organism is the causative agent of endemic and venereal syphilis. This sexual transmitted disease was first discovered in Europe at the end of the fifteenth century, however, the causative agent was not identified until 1905. At one time syphilis was the third most commonly reported communicable disease in the USA. Syphilis is characterized by multiple clinical stages and long periods of latent, asymptomatic infection. Although effective therapies have been available since the introduction of penicillin, syphilis remains a global health problem.

Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum strain Nichols. This strain was originally isolated in 1912 from a neurosyphilitic patient and is virulent.

StructuredCitation.Title: Complete genome sequence of Treponema pallidum, the syphilis spirochete.

Author.Consortium: Institute for Genomic Research, Rockville, MD 20850, USA. tpdb@tigr.org

Organism.OrganismName: Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum str. Nichols

ProjectDescr.Name: Campylobacter fetus subsp. venerealis str. Azul-94
ProjectDescr.Title: Causes infertility, infectious abortions, septicemia, meningitis
ProjectDescr.Description: Campylobacter fetus subsp. venerealis str. Azul-94. Field isolate obtained from an aborted Bos taurus (cow) fetus (Year: 1994, Place: Tandil, Argentina).

StructuredCitation.Title: Genomic analysis of Campylobacter fetus subspecies: identification of candidate virulence determinants and diagnostic assay targets.

Author.Consortium: Centre for Comparative Genomics, School for Information Technology, Murdoch University, Murdoch, Western Australia, Australia. pmoolhuijzen@ccg.murdoch.edu.au

Organism.OrganismName: Campylobacter fetus subsp. venerealis str. Azul-94

ProjectDescr.Name: Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168 = ATCC 700819
ProjectDescr.Title: Leading cause of food poisoning (altered virulence strain)
ProjectDescr.Description: Campylobacter jejuni strain NCTC11168. This strain (originally 5636/77) was isolated from a diarrheic patient in 1977 and minimally passaged. This strain displays aberrant virulence phenotypes in animal models and tissue culture. Contains many homopolymeric tracts in the genome which result in hypervariable sequences in many genes having to do with cell surface structures. These sequences result in hypervarible antigenic diversity and immune evasion. Overall, the genome contains very few repetitive DNA sequences and very few coding regions arranged in operons. Pathogenicity factors include cytolethal-distending toxin, hemolysin-like toxins, and a type II secretion system.

StructuredCitation.Title: The genome sequence of the food-borne pathogen Campylobacter jejuni reveals hypervariable sequences.

Author.Consortium: The Sanger Centre, The Wellcome Trust Genome Campus, Hinxton, Cambridge, UK.

StructuredCitation.Title: Re-annotation and re-analysis of the Campylobacter jejuni NCTC11168 genome sequence.

Author.Consortium: Pathogen Molecular Department, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, UK. Ozan.gundogdu@lshtm.ac.uk <Ozan.gundogdu@lshtm.ac.uk>

Organism.OrganismName: Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168 = ATCC 700819
